intro: Morus alba var. colombassa, commonly known as the Colombian mulberry, is a variant of the white mulberry native to South America. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters, featuring heart-shaped leaves with a smooth texture. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits known as mulberries, which are edible and often consumed by both humans and animals. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, preferring well-drained soil and full sunlight. This variety is also valued for its role in traditional medicine and as a source of fiber for textile production.
